turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Apartheid-era South Africa and the Olympics.
turn.1: Why did South Africa boycott the Olympics?
turn.2: Apartheid-era South Africa and the Olympics  South Africa did not compete at Olympic Games from 1964 to 1988, as a part of the sporting boycott of South Africa during the apartheid era.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: The South African National Olympic Committee (NOC) was expelled from the International Olympic Committee (IOC) in 1970.
turn.5: Did they ever return to the Olympics?
turn.6: In 1991, as part of the transition to multiracial equality, a new NOC was formed and admitted to the IOC, and the country competed at the 1992 Summer Olympics.
turn.7: What other issues did they have with the Olympics?
turn.8: All sport in South Africa under apartheid was segregated by race, with separate clubs and governing bodies.
turn.9: Did this relate to their Olympic boycott?
turn.10: Only white bodies were affiliated to the "South African Olympic and Empire" [later "Commonwealth"] "Games Association" (SAOEGA, later SAOCGA) so only white South Africans competed at the Olympic Games and the Empire (later Commonwealth) Games.
turn.12: The IOC under Avery Brundage regarded this as an internal matter for South Africa, and, committed to keeping politics and sports separate, took no action.
